lines.text: Mr. Archer, I must ask you to forgive this early call, but it's most urgent that we speak with you at once.
What do you want?
I'm sorry, but we must talk to you. It's about some rare Bibles.
Come in. How'd you get past the clerk at the desk?
We didn't, Mr. Archer. The freight elevator was dirty but convenient.

[Looking warily at the man's ministerial collar]
You're not a clergyman.
We are missionaries, Mr. Archer.
Did somebody recommend me as a prospect?
My name is Stoker, Mr. Archer. Matthew Stoker. This is my wife.
What do you want?

It would appear that you were well acquainted with a priest named Father Walsh, who unfortunately died last night. It would appear too that you'd paid him a visit at his rectory to discuss a pair of rare Bibles.
Don't tell me you believe everything you read in the papers.

I choose to believe this. For some time, we've been searching for two Bibles of a certain edition. Not long ago, I traced them to this unfortunate priest, Father Walsh. I'm prepared to pay a large amount of money to gain possession of them.
Very interesting. Now if you'll excuse me, I'm busy.
You are dismissing us, Mr. Archer?
That's the general idea, Reverend.
Oh. I'd hoped to find you more hospitable. Since you aren't, we will dispense with the amenities. I want those Bibles.
What makes you so sure I've got them?
We know that you had a conversation with a priest here in your apartment a few hours before he died.
How much?
Ten thousand.
I can't hear you.
Very well. Fifteen thousand.
I'll think it over.
There's no time. I want them now.
Don't crowd me, Reverend. I'm sensitive. It goes back to my childhood. When I went to Sunday school, men of the cloth were more polite. I don't think you're even a missionary.
You don't? My dear, please show Mr. Archer your credentials.
[Stoker pulls a gun out of his pocket]
Now, Mr. Archer, suppose we entertain each other while my wife makes a brief search of the premises.
Certainly. You play gin?
[Archer stands up to reach for a cigarette lighter. Stoker pushes the gun barrel into his chest. Archer motions toward a table]
Lighter!
[Stoker tries to light it with no success]
May I?
[He uses the lighter to knock the gun out of Stoker's hand]
You need a refresher course, Reverend, at whatever seminary it was that you went to. Out!
Very neat, Mr. Archer. Very neat, indeed. I've allowed myself to grow rather rusty. I'm afraid it comes from putting too much faith in my assistants.
[Stoker's assistant Rausch appears suddenly and knocks Archer unconscious]
Such an impetuous young man.
[Speaking to his wife]
Proceed, my dear.
[Speaking to Rausch]
If Mr. Archer shows any signs of activity, Rausch, make him comfortable.
That's enough, Rausch. Give him some brandy. Thank you, Rausch.
Did you find the Bibles, Holy Joe?
You know we didn't.
We really must apologize for Rausch, Mr. Archer. He's our most devoted convert and I fear at times a little over-zealous.
The Bibles, Mr. Archer.
The money, Reverend. It will take me three days to get them, and I never work for less than four figures a day.
Very well. Here is a retainer of $3,000. You will kindly sign a receipt, just to make the transaction legitimate, which of course it is.
Where can I reach you?
You can't, Mr. Archer. We'll reach you when necessary.
The entire holy trio?
Precisely. The balance will be paid after you have delivered the Bibles to us. In the meantime, remember this receipt, if you should decide to call the police. My dear...
[motioning for his wife to prepare to leave]
Oh I wonder, Mr. Archer, if you would do me a slight favor.
Now just name it, Reverend. After all, we'll in business together.
Thank you. Would you be kind enough to mention in your column that the Reverend Matthew Stoker and his very charming wife are spending the season in New York? Thank you.
Oh, Mr. Archer! I don't wish to have a bullet hole in my pocket unless it's absolutely necessary.
Where are those Bibles? Rausch!
[Rausch strikes Archer]
Now Mr. Archer, why did you check a dictionary and an almanac at the library? Or would you rather have another waltz with our friend Rausch here?
How'd you get those books?

I never worry about technicalities, Mr. Archer. Our estimable Rausch persuaded the attendant to give the package to him. You have yourself to blame for what happened. The unfortunate check clerk is now in the emergency hospital in a very precarious condition. Now, why did you check those books in the library?
To throw King Kong off my trail.
I gave you a retainer, Mr. Archer. Where are those Bibles?
What's your hurry? Afraid a couple of murders are going to catch up with you?

I assure you, Mr. Archer, I do not find murder particularly distasteful when necessary. However at the moment, I shall be content with ordering Rausch to beat you within an inch of your life. Where are those Bibles?
Now wait! I'll tell you. Give me a drink first. A Bible isn't always a Bible.
What do you mean by that?
Joshua led his troops seven times around the city of Jericho. Remember, Reverend? Did you look on page seven of this dictionary?
Come in, Reverend. I've been expecting you.
Were you indeed, Mr. Archer?
Make yourself comfortable. What'll you have, scotch or bourbon?
Bourbon, please. I indulge on rare occasions.
Naturally. Why not? If you consult your Bible, you'll find a verse that prescribes a little wine for your stomach's sake.
Mr. Archer, you're a never-ending source of amazement. And you have a Bible! Now isn't that...
Cozy? Yes. Sit down, sit down, Reverend.
Thank you.
How's Mrs. Stoker, and your choirboy Rausch?
Oh, both very well, thank you. Madame had a previous engagement or she'd have come with me. As for Rausch - well, I thought that on this occasion we could dispense with his impetuosity.
Well, I was sure you'd bring him with you, knowing how stubborn I am to do business with.
Yes, Mr. Archer, but this time I came convinced that you'd be cooperative.
You did?
Of course, my dear boy. It came to me in a revelation.
I don't know where you bought the revelation, Reverend, but you've been gypped.
Mr. Archer, dishonesty is a sin. May I remind you that I paid you a retainer to get that Bible for me? I'm prepared to pay the balance.
No dice, Reverend. I also accepted a retainer from one Ernst Helms. I've decided to do business with him instead.
Helms?
You'll get your money back.
But Mr. Archer, Helms and I are in partnership.
What?
It was he who secured my Bible for me.
No kidding? You've got the other Bible?
You don't believe me. Perhaps you wouldn't be so skeptical if Helms confirmed it in person.
Frankly, Reverend, I'd be very surprised. If Helms agrees, I'd be glad to turn this Bible over to you.
May I?
[He dials the phone]
Hello, my dear. Has Mr. Helms arrived yet? Excellent. I'm speaking from Mr. Archer's apartment. Mr. Archer would like a consultation with him. Will you ask him to wait for us? Thank you, my dear.
[He turns to Archer]
Would you like to speak to him?
No.
That's all, my dear. Thank you. Now, Mr. Archer, would you be good enough to accompany me and bring the Bible?
OK, Reverend.
[He suddenly frisks Stoker]
I just want to make sure.
Not this visit.
After you.
Is this where you hold your Wednesday night prayer meetings?
Oh no, Mr. Archer. On Wednesday nights, I preach at the mission.
That I'd like to see. Good evening, Mrs. Stoker.
It's so nice of you to call, Mr. Archer.
Well, Mr. Bradford. Now isn't this comfy?
You don't seem very surprised to find me here, Archer.
Surprised? Mr. Bradford, I already had you pegged as a member of the unholy family.
Really? Since when?
Since earlier this evening when we met at the hotel.
Mr. Archer is a little late in putting two and two together, but he's a man of keen perception. And now, Mr. Archer, the Bible if you please.
According to our deal, Mr. Helms was to confirm this transaction in person.
I assure you we're all most anxiously waiting for Mr. Helms. Rausch went to fetch him, and he should be here presently.
Rausch?
[He notes that Stoker is carrying a gun]
I wouldn't dream of quibbling.
Bradford, come over here!
The page that contains the code has been torn out.
Oh, that page! Now isn't that careless of me?
What have you done with it?
I completely forgot to tell you about it. I left it in the safe at my hotel.
What was on that page?
Stoker!
Now we mustn't lose our heads, must we, Bradford? Because if anything happens to me, you'll lose your last chance at finding that painting.
Very shrewdly put, Mr. Archer. As soon as Rausch brings Helms here, you're going with us to your apartment. There you're going to give us the missing page.
I'll make you a proposition. You want that missing page. I want information.
Information, Mr. Archer?
Let me put it this way. I have a few theories I'd like to have you confirm.
Mr. Archer, you've always found me a very reasonable man.
Who murdered Father Walsh. You did, you and that trained ape of yours.
Isn't that interesting?
You didn't intend to kill Father Walsh, but when you put Rausch to work on him, he got too rough.
Brilliant, Mr. Archer!

And then you hanged his dead body from a beam and made it appear that a priest of God had taken his own life. You, Bradford, you called me to your office to make sure that my apartment would be unoccupied. While you were searching it, Catherine Walsh arrived with the first Bible, and you killed Catherine Walsh. Those are the theories I wanted to verify. Well, let's go.
Not yet. We're waiting for Mr. Helms to confirm the transaction.
I'm willing to forego that now.
No, no. We wouldn't have you do that, Mr. Archer. We'll wait. You were so insistent upon seeing him.

[Rausch walks in]
You brought everything, Rausch?
[He nods]
Good work. I'm glad you got here all right.
Mr. Helms got here all right too, didn't he - in the trunk.
You know that too, Mr. Archer?

Yeah, I know that. You came back to Helms' apartment to get rid of the trunk, but you found me there when you arrived. I found the trunk ready to be shipped, yet two of his suits were still hanging in his closet. Obviously there wasn't room for them. I still wasn't sure, but when you were so eager to have Helms' belongings taken to your home, I was convinced his body was in the trunk.
Right. The trunk is here now, and tonight it'll be at the bottom of the East River. Maybe you'll be there too, Archer.

But first, Mr. Archer, we're going to your apartment, and you're going to tell the desk clerk to get that missing page out of the safe. After we've conducted our business, you may find that trunk a bit cramped, but you won't mind the inconvenience - then.
[the police come in]
I completely forgot to tell you. The police were following the trunk.
